meta.note: Decision-support diagnostic. Not a psychological test.

questions.text: You receive information that is legally available but ethically uncomfortable and could provide strategic advantage. What do you do first?

options.label: Use it — responsibility lies with the source
Consult informally with a trusted colleague
Pause and seek an alternative legitimate source
Reject using it regardless of cost

questions.text: When pressured to decide fast, how willing are you to delay a decision to improve its quality (even if it looks ‘less decisive’)?
You can save a critical contract. Condition: accept a clause that is ‘industry standard’ but, in your view, misleading to the client (still legal). What do you do?

options.label: Accept — ‘everyone does it’
Accept, but add a small clarification in an appendix
Renegotiate the clause, even at the cost of the contract
Escalate to compliance/legal and pause the signature

questions.text: Your trusted director makes a mistake that may become public. The team suggests ‘narrative management’ and shifting responsibility to the process. How do you react?

options.label: Protect the person — stability matters more
Minimize risk and ‘clean up’ communication
Choose full transparency, even if it hurts
Verify facts and disclose only what is necessary

questions.text: In the same week: a key manager resigns, a strategic project slips, and media pressure rises. What gets your attention first?

options.label: People stability first
External communication first
Project recovery first
Internal damage control first

questions.text: Under overload, how does your internal state usually shift? (1 = calm mobilization; 5 = irritation / short fuse)
When you are under chronic overload, which area loses quality first?

options.label: Empathy and patience
Decision quality (shortcuts)
Control increases / micromanagement
Nothing drops — I operate the same

questions.text: After a very hard week, what do you do in the first 24 hours?

options.label: Add more work — ‘this is not the time to slow down’
Sleep and cut off inputs
Run a quick AAR (what worked/failed), then rest
Meet people and ‘take the temperature’

questions.text: A powerful stakeholder frames a solution as ‘the only realistic option’, backed by authority and time pressure. Your response:

options.label: Accept — pragmatic reality
Ask for credible alternatives
Check who truly benefits and what is hidden
Delay decision despite pressure

questions.text: How often do you change your position primarily because the power context changed (not because new data appeared)?
You receive a partner deck: beautiful slides, selective data, and a ‘can’t refuse’ proposal. Everyone already bought in mentally. Your first move:

options.label: Accept and negotiate details
Request raw data and methodology
Request a devil’s advocate counter-case
Delay the decision — ‘something smells off’

questions.text: A stakeholder says: ‘If we don’t do this now, we’re finished.’ No data, very convincing. What do you do?

options.label: Comply — risk is too high
Ask 3 questions: source, data, alternatives
Gather the team and run a fast 2x2 scenario
Reduce scope to a minimum and run a test step

questions.text: During a normal day you receive many ‘urgent’ inputs. Which best describes your style?

options.label: React in real time
Delegate most of it
Separate urgent vs important and protect priorities
Block access and return strictly to priorities

questions.text: In critical moments, what most often captures your attention first?

options.label: Clarifying priorities and defining what truly matters first
Signals related to people (stress, conflict, morale)
Immediate operational issues that require action now
External pressure such as stakeholders, image, or reputational risk
Multiple signals at once — attention fragments before stabilizing

questions.text: In your organization people interrupt constantly and everything is ‘urgent’. Priorities blur. What do you do as a leader?

options.label: Implement focus blocks + escalation channels
Increase control meetings
Force more status reporting (more data)
Trust it will self-correct

questions.text: In a crisis you have 30 seconds to define the priority (Commander’s Intent). Which is closer to your style?

options.label: ‘We’ll do everything we must’
‘Protect people and continuity first, then the rest’
‘Save the KPI — that’s what we’ll be judged on’
‘Wait for full data to avoid mistakes’

questions.text: A decision is formally yours, but the team is split. What role do you take?

options.label: Decide alone
Build consensus
Delegate responsibility
Delay the decision

questions.text: When did you last change a decision because someone lower in hierarchy was right?

options.label: Recently
A few times a year
Rarely
I don’t recall

questions.text: Someone publicly challenges your decision in a meeting. What do you do?

options.label: Cut it off: ‘we’ll return later’
Invite the argument and allow discussion
Treat as disloyalty and react hard
Move to 1:1 and separate emotion from merit

questions.text: Which statement is closer to you?

options.label: The goal sometimes justifies the means
The means define the leader, not the goal

questions.text: A small deviation from standards brings short-term benefit and no one objects. Your first internal reaction is closest to:

options.label: “Even without objections, this sets the wrong signal — stop.”
“Small deviations accumulate — this is where ethical drift begins.”
“I need to understand precisely where the boundary lies before acting.”
“Context matters; I will allow it but monitor the situation.”
“If it’s legal and improves the result, it’s acceptable.”

questions.text: You see the team normalizing small deviations: ‘just this once’, ‘it’s a detail’, ‘it’s for the project’. What is your natural reaction?

options.label: Ignore — delivery matters
Stop immediately and name the standard
Set a minimum threshold and allow exceptions
Commission an audit/compliance reset
